title: 109_hr3372
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Trademark Defense Act of 2005". It includes findings and purpose. The United States Trademark Defense Act of 2005 recognizes the importance of trademarks and trade names for American businesses engaged in international trade. Sales of branded products contribute to the livelihood of American workers and the growth of businesses, dependent on protection under international agreements like TRIPS and the Paris Convention. The United States Trademark Defense Act of 2005 emphasizes the significance of trademarks and trade names for American businesses in international trade. It highlights the need for protecting trademarks abroad and ensuring compliance with intellectual property rights treaties. Additionally, many US businesses have registered trademarks in Cuba to secure exclusive rights for future use post-trade embargo lift. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 allows US businesses to export branded food products to Cuba. A court ruling affirmed that a section of the Department of Commerce Appropriations Act abrogates the General Inter-American Convention on Trade Mark and Commercial Protection with respect to Cuba. Cuba has an international remedy under customary law for a breach by the US of the Convention. The General Inter-American Convention on Trade Mark and Commercial Protection aims to suspend or revoke Cuba's protection of US trademarks. Since 1996, US businesses have registered thousands of European trademarks to secure exclusive rights in the European Union. The World Trade Organization ruled that a US law is inconsistent with international intellectual property agreements. The World Trade Organization ruled that the United States must bring its law into conformity with international intellectual property agreements. Failure to do so may result in compensation and the suspension of concessions by the European Community. Additionally, the United States must repeal a specific section to preserve trademark rights in Cuba, the European Union, and other countries. The Department of Commerce and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1999, aims to protect trademarks, trade names, and domain names of US nationals abroad. Section 211 of the Act is deemed unnecessary for courts to ensure equitable outcomes for foreign nationals' trademark rights affected by government confiscation. The purpose of the Act is to improve compliance with international intellectual property obligations and defend US intellectual property interests from suspension of benefits abroad. It aims to protect trademarks and trade names of foreign nationals affected by confiscation, allowing courts to consider relevant legal and equitable issues. The Act repeals Section 211 of the Department of Commerce and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1999 and authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to issue necessary regulations. Additionally, it grants authority to courts. SEC. 4. AUTHORITY OF COURTS. United States courts can recognize and enforce rights in a mark or trade name based on common law or registration. SEC. 5. PROTECTION OF UNITED STATES INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS. SEC. 5. PROTECTION OF UNITED STATES INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS. The United States Trade Representative will examine Cuba's policies on intellectual property rights for the 2005 report. Consideration will be given to countries that do not provide adequate protection for intellectual property rights.
